author: BBC News
description:
Today, the Institute for Fiscal Studies has warned the UK chancellor she’s risking being stuck in ‘Groundhog Day’ when it comes to her upcoming Autumn budget.

Adam is joined by Faisal, who’s been speaking to Chancellor Reeves at the IMF summit in Washington DC, and Helen Miller, director of the IFS, who have published their Green Budget document today. They discuss why Rachel Reeves should fear being stuck in an economic doomloop, the taxes that could rise in November’s budget, and what Rachel Reeves has said to Faisal about ‘targeted action’ on inflation and the cost of living. 

And, BBC Security Correspondent Frank Gardener has been at a lock-in listening to the MI5 boss Sir Ken McCallum giving his annual speech on threats to the UK. Adam and Frank discuss what Sir Ken said about the UK’s relationship with China, following this week’s collapsed China spy case.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews
title: Is Rachel Reeves facing ‘Groundhog Day’ in her upcoming budget? | BBC Newscast

author: BBC News
description:
The number of households in England living in temporary accommodation is at a record high, government figures show.
 
More than 132,000 households were living in temporary accommodation on 30 June 2025, up 7.6% from the same time last year. That includes more than 172,000 children.
 
Mum of three, Danielle, from west London, has moved four times in a year after she was forced out of her flat when the landlord sold up.
 
UK Homelessness Minister, Alison McGovern said: "Today's statistics are a harsh reminder that too many have been let down by the system meant to protect them.”
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#UK #Homeless #BBCNews
title: ‘Homeless with three kids’ | BBC News

author: BBC News
description:
US President Donald Trump had said he will meet Russian President Vladimir Putin in Hungary for more talks on ending the war in Ukraine, following a "very productive" phone call between the pair.
 
Trump said fresh talks will be held between "high level advisers" next week, led on the US side by Secretary of State Marco Rubio.
 
Putin's special envoy Kirill Dmitriev said the call between Russia's President and Donald Trump was "positive and productive".
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#DonaldTrump #VladimirPutin #BBCNews
title: Donald Trump says he will meet Vladimir Putin for Ukraine talks in Hungary | BBC News

author: BBC News
description:
A major legal claim has been filed in the UK against pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson, accusing the firm of knowingly selling baby powder contaminated with asbestos.
 
The claim involves 3,000 people and focuses on internal memos and scientific reports, which have been seen by the BBC.
 
The lawsuit - brought by KP Law - alleges that Johnson & Johnson (J&J) was aware as early as the 1960s that its mineral-based talcum powder contained fibrous forms of talc, as well as tremolite and actinolite. Both minerals are classified as asbestos and linked to potentially deadly cancers.
 
J&J denies the allegation as well as any claims it knowingly sold baby powder contaminated with asbestos.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#UK #Johnson&Johnson #BBCNews
title: Thousands in UK sue Johnson & Johnson over talcum powder cancer risks | BBC News

author: BBC News
description:
Sudan is currently experiencing one of the world's worst humanitarian emergencies.
 
According to the UN, three million children under the age of five are acutely malnourished. The hospitals there are left overwhelmed.
 
Bashaer Hospital is one of the last functioning hospitals in Sudan's capital, Khartoum, devastated by the civil war which has been raging since April 2023. Many people travel hours to get to the hospital for specialist care.
 
Across the whole of Khartoum, children's lives have been rewritten by the civil war.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Sudan #Africa #BBCNews
title: Children caught up in Sudan’s deadly civil war | BBC News

author: BBC News
description:
French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu has survived two no-confidence votes, after his pledge to suspend pension reform wins him the support of left-wing MPs.
 
He narrowly won the first motion by 18 votes and survived the second, brought by the far right, by a larger margin.
 
Marine Le Pen of the far-right National Rally previously said "this isn't a political crisis, it's a crisis of politicians”.
 
Lecornu only became PM in September.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#France #FrenchPolitics #BBCNews
title: French PM Sébastien Lecornu survives no-confidence votes | BBC News

author: BBC News
description:
Israel has said it decided not to allow the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt to be opened unless Hamas makes a “greater effort” on the issue of returning deceased hostages.
 
The Israeli defence body, Cogat, said the date for the crossing to be re-opened “for the movement of people only will be announced at a later stage”. It added that preparations were ongoing with Egypt.
 
As part of the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire plan, Hamas had to return 20 living hostages and the bodies of another 28 hostages.
 
In return 250 Palestinian prisoners and about 1,700 detainees were released by Israel.
 
The US is downplaying the threat to the Gaza ceasefire deal after Hamas says it needs more time to find the remaining bodies of Israeli hostages.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Israel #Gaza #BBCNews
title: Israel says Rafah crossing won't reopen for aid | BBC News
